generif.text: expressed strongly in heart, skeletal muscle, and kidney, less in placenta, lung, and liver, and weakly in brain and blood cells. Electrophysiological study showed that KCNE4 modulates the activation of the KCNQ1 channel.
KCNE4 beta-subunit has a drastic inhibitory effect on currents generated by Kv1.1 and Kv1.3 potassium channels
Based upon previous studies and the present results, it is concluded that both hKCNE4 and mKCNE4 have a drastic inhibitory impact on both hKCNQ1 and mKCNQ1 currents.
KCNE4 E145D polymorphism may be related to atrial fibrillation.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
The non-synonymous single nucleotide polymorphism E145D may be associated with the atrial fibrillation phenotype.
KCNE4 directly associates with KCNQ1, and can co-associate together with KCNE1 in the same KCNQ1 complex to form a 'triple subunit' complex (KCNE1-KCNQ1-KCNE4).
MiRP3 (encoded by the KCNE4 gene) plays a role in modulation of BK-dependent urinary potassium excretion.

Specific KCNE4 domains responsible for the inhibitory effects on heterologously expressed KCNQ1 were identified. The KCNE4 C-terminus is critical for KCNQ1 modulation and physically interacts with KCNQ1.
KCNE4 (potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily E member 4), but not KCNE2, functions as an inhibitory Kv1.3 partner in leukocytes.
MiRP3 modulates Kv4.2 current activation, inactivation and recovery from inactivation. MiRP3 shifts the half-maximal voltage for activation and slows time to peak ~ 100%.
KCNE4 juxtamembrane region is required for interaction with calmodulin and for functional suppression of KCNQ1.
the association of the KCNE4 gene variability with allergic rhinitis

Reported here are previously undiscovered protein-coding regions in exon 1 of hKCNE3 and hKCNE4 that extend their encoded extracellular domains by 44 and 51 residues, which yields full-length proteins of 147 and 221 residues, respectively.
the tertiary structure of the C-terminal domain of Kv1.3 is necessary and sufficient for Kv1.3- KCNE4 interaction.
Regulation of human cardiac potassium channels by full-length KCNE3 and KCNE4 has been reported.
The KCNE1 (rs1805127) appears to an independent risk factor for AF in the Uygur population. And the KCNE4 (rs12621643) was an independent risk factor for AF among both Uygurs and Hans.

experimental data and the in silico structure suggest that the KCNE4 interaction hides a forward-trafficking motif within Kv1.3 in addition to adding a strong endoplasmic reticulum retention signature to the Kv1.3-KCNE4 complex.
Calmodulin-dependent KCNE4 dimerization controls membrane targeting.
KCNE4-dependent functional consequences of Kv1.3-related leukocyte physiology.
Induction of potassium channel regulator KCNE4 in a submandibular lymph node metastasis model.
KCNE4 expression is correlated with the pathological characteristics of colorectal cancer patients and associated with the radioresistance of cancer cells.
Vitamin D Receptor Deficiency Upregulates Pulmonary Artery Kv7 Channel Activity.

interpro.desc: Potassium channel, voltage-dependent, beta subunit, KCNE

name: potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily E regulatory subunit 4
other_names: cardiac voltage-gated potassium channel accessory subunit 4
potassium channel, voltage gated subfamily E regulatory beta subunit 4
potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily E member 4
potassium voltage-gated channel, Isk-related family, member 4
summary: Voltage-gated potassium (Kv) channels represent the most complex class of voltage-gated ion channels from both functional and structural standpoints. Their diverse functions include regulating neurotransmitter release, heart rate, insulin secretion, neuronal excitability, epithelial electrolyte transport, smooth muscle contraction, and cell volume. This gene encodes a member of the potassium channel, voltage-gated, isk-related subfamily. This member is a type I membrane protein, and a beta subunit that assembles with a potassium channel alpha-subunit to modulate the gating kinetics and enhance stability of the multimeric complex. This gene is prominently expressed in the embryo and in adult uterus. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
